stem: The nurse is caring for a patient experiencing increased intracranial pressure (ICP) following an ischemic stroke. Based on the patient data, prioritize the interventions in order of importance, with the MOST important intervention listed first.

itemContext.sbar: S: Mr. Smith is a 68-year-old male admitted at 07:00 today with right-sided weakness and slurred speech, suspected ischemic stroke. B: History includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes. Last lisinopril 20mg PO at 06:00. A: At 10:00, GCS is 12 (E3, V4, M5). Right-sided weakness persists; increasing restlessness and confusion noted. Vitals: BP 180/100 mmHg, HR 92 bpm, RR 24 (labored), SpO2 94% on 2L NC, Temp 37.5°C. Pupils equal at 3mm, sluggishly reactive. Labs pending. Radiology: CT head ordered. MAR: Lisinopril, Acetaminophen PRN, Nicardipine IV drip initiated at 10:15. A: Suspect increased ICP. Immediate interventions: frequent LOC assessment, antihypertensive administration per protocol, elevate head of bed to 30 degrees, prepare for potential intubation if respiratory status declines. Close monitoring is essential.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content: S: Mr. Smith is a 68-year-old male admitted at 07:00 today with right-sided weakness and slurred speech, suspected ischemic stroke. B: History includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes. Last lisinopril 20mg PO at 06:00. A: At 10:00, GCS is 12 (E3, V4, M5). Right-sided weakness persists; increasing restlessness and confusion noted. Vitals: BP 180/100 mmHg, HR 92 bpm, RR 24 (labored), SpO2 94% on 2L NC, Temp 37.5°C. Pupils equal at 3mm, sluggishly reactive. Labs pending. Radiology: CT head ordered. MAR: Lisinopril, Acetaminophen PRN, Nicardipine IV drip initiated at 10:15. A: Suspect increased ICP. Immediate interventions: frequent LOC assessment, antihypertensive administration per protocol, elevate head of bed to 30 degrees, prepare for potential intubation if respiratory status declines. Close monitoring is essential.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: Na: 140 mEq/L, K: 4.2 mEq/L, Cl: 100 mEq/L, Glucose: 180 mg/dL, BUN: 20 mg/dL, Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL, INR: 1.0, Platelets: 200K/uL, WBC: 9.0 K/uL

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: 07:00: BP 160/90 mmHg, HR 88 bpm, RR 20, SpO2 96% on RA, Temp 37.0°C; 08:00: BP 170/95 mmHg, HR 90 bpm, RR 22, SpO2 95% on 2L NC, Temp 37.2°C; 09:00: BP 175/98 mmHg, HR 91 bpm, RR 23, SpO2 94% on 2L NC, Temp 37.4°C; 10:00: BP 180/100 mmHg, HR 92 bpm, RR 24, SpO2 94% on 2L NC, Temp 37.5°C

tabs.title: Radiology
tabs.content: CT head ordered at 10:05, results pending.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Lisinopril 20mg PO Daily (06:00), Acetaminophen 650mg PO PRN for headache (last given 08:00), Nicardipine IV Drip per protocol (initiated 10:15, titrate to maintain SBP <160 mmHg), Oxygen 2L NC

rationale.correct: 1. Titrate Nicardipine IV drip: Rapidly lowering blood pressure is crucial to reducing cerebral edema and preventing further neurological damage. The SBP >160 mmHg needs immediate attention to prevent further increases in ICP and the risk of hemorrhagic conversion. ClinicalPearl: Aim for controlled reduction, not precipitous drops. 2. Elevate the head of the bed to 30 degrees: This promotes venous drainage from the brain, reducing ICP. Elevating the head of the bed is a fundamental nursing intervention for patients with increased ICP. ClinicalPearl: Ensure proper alignment to avoid neck compression, which can impede venous return. 3. Administer Acetaminophen: Elevated temperature increases metabolic demand in the brain, exacerbating ICP. Reducing fever is essential to minimize further neurological damage and improve patient outcomes. ClinicalPearl: Monitor for effectiveness and consider alternative routes if the patient's LOC decreases. 4. Decrease environmental stimuli: Minimizing external stimuli can help reduce agitation and prevent further increases in ICP. The patient is already restless and confused, which can further increase ICP. Reducing stimuli will help to calm the patient and prevent further exacerbation of ICP. ClinicalPearl: Cluster care activities to allow for periods of rest and reduced stimulation.
rationale.incorrect: Administering Acetaminophen before controlling the blood pressure is incorrect because uncontrolled hypertension contributes directly to increased ICP and potential hemorrhagic conversion in the setting of a stroke. Decreasing environmental stimuli should only be done AFTER addressing the hypertension, because the hypertension is causing the increase in ICP and addressing that is most important.
clinicalPearls: Hypertension management is critical in acute stroke to prevent further cerebral edema and potential hemorrhagic conversion.
Elevating the head of the bed is a simple but effective intervention to reduce ICP.
Fever increases metabolic demand in the brain and can worsen neurological outcomes.
Careful neurological monitoring is essential to detect changes in condition and guide interventions.

questionTrap.trap: Students may prioritize administering acetaminophen first if they focus solely on the elevated temperature without recognizing the immediate threat posed by uncontrolled hypertension.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) and then neurological status. Uncontrolled hypertension is a direct threat to cerebral perfusion and can lead to further neurological damage. Also, think about the pathophysiology of increased ICP and the interventions that directly address that.

mnemonic.title: ICP Management
mnemonic.expansion: Elevate Head (30 degrees), Control BP, Prevent Fever, Reduce Stimuli
